RESPONSE TEXT: Lobsters have blue blood.
Some species of hermit crabs can live up to 70 years and grow to the size of a coconut.
The bite of a Great White Shark can exceed fourty thousand pounds per square inch.
A Swordfish will use its bill to lash out and stun prey and possess a special organ to heat their brain and eyes.
Belcher's Sea Snake is the most venomous snake in the world. A few milligrams of venom is enough to kill hundreds of people.
Members of the Scorpaenidae family, such as the Lionfish, possess a sharp dorsal spine coated in a venemous mucus.
Certain species of catfish are equipped with spines long enough to pierce a human heart or lungs.
When bifurcated, some starfish can regenerate into two separate starfish.
When threatened, the Puffer Fish will blow itself up to more than twice its original size to scare off predators.
A single mouthful of seawater may contain hundreds of thousands of Phytoplankton.
The average depth of the Atlantic Ocean is 3,928 meters.
Growing to a length of over a meter, the Geoduck is the worlds largest clam. They can live over 150 years.
SCRIPT NOTES: Geoduck is pronounced "gooey duck".

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Bartender: You came to the right place, darling. I've got the best vodka money can buy.

DIALOGUE AFTER: Bartender: Well... it appears I finally have a customer who wants to show a little class.
SCRIPT NOTES: Friendly - Making polite conversation, gets a little worried toward the end when he discusses losing pieces. / Friendly

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Bartender: Well... it appears I finally have a customer who wants to show a little class.
RESPONSE TEXT: Oh my, the very idea! I thank you for the warning, sir. I shall keep all eyes open.
SCRIPT NOTES: Shocked at the idea of people kidnapping him to sell and thankful for the warning. / Grateful

DIALOGUE BEFORE: myActor: Oh, they have a bar down here?
RESPONSE TEXT: Greetings, sir. And what's the house speciality of this fine establishment?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Bartender: You came to the right place, darling. I've got the best vodka money can buy.
SCRIPT NOTES: Asking a genuine question. / Question

RESPONSE TEXT: Ah, is that a Protectron over there?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Bartender: Nan-ni shimasho-ka?
SCRIPT NOTES: Curious - asking a question. / Question

DIALOGUE BEFORE: myActor: Be right back, gonna grab a quick drink.
RESPONSE TEXT: Greetings, sir. Good to see another robot in town. That chef hat becomes you.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Bartender: Nan-ni shimasho-ka?
SCRIPT NOTES: Happy and friendly - Talking to a protectron in Diamond City wearing a chef hat. / Friendly

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Bartender: Nan-ni shimasho-ka?
RESPONSE TEXT: Takahashi you say? I'm Codsworth, a pleasure to make your acquaintance.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Bartender: Nan-ni shimasho-ka?
SCRIPT NOTES: Friendly - making polite introductions. / Friendly

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Bartender: Nan-ni shimasho-ka?
RESPONSE TEXT: Is that so? Well, we both know RobCo is no General Atomics. It's not surprising it failed, shoddy work and all.
SCRIPT NOTES: Friendly - Responding to another robot's woes. A bit of disgust at the mention of the company "RobCo". / Friendly

RESPONSE TEXT: Chin up, though. Never know when parts may turn up.
SCRIPT NOTES: Friendly - trying to cheer up another robot. / Friendly

RESPONSE TEXT: Feeling a bit thirsty, sir?
SCRIPT NOTES: Asking a question - they just stepped near a bar. / Question

RESPONSE TEXT: Feeling a bit thirsty, mum?
SCRIPT NOTES: Asking a question - they just stepped near a bar. / Question

RESPONSE TEXT: I suppose if I had the hardware, I'd have the software as well. I'd hate to see how that'd affect my honesty and manner settings.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned - Thinking about how different he'd be if he didn't have honesty and manner settings. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Indeed. Perhaps I should rethink my initial desire.
SCRIPT NOTES: Reconsidering what he thought was a good idea. / Thinking

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: They've got something they use to control us, to make us do things we don't want to do.
RESPONSE TEXT: My word! This certainly does not conform to my hospitality subroutines.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Phyllis: Any second now they might send some signal, or I'll see the color orange, or whatever it is they do and BOOM.
SCRIPT NOTES: Surprised

DIALOGUE BEFORE: RetreatSceneActor: Damn it!
RESPONSE TEXT: We shall fight another day!
SCRIPT NOTES: Canceling pursuit of the player. / Afraid

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Roger: Now he's starting to work on my wife and kids, trying to turn them against me too.
RESPONSE TEXT: Turning family against family is a fiendish act.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: They just need to be convinced Bill's wrong. That won't be hard.
SCRIPT NOTES: Disapproving / Concerned

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I know you're in a tough situation here, but lives are at stake. Please help me.
RESPONSE TEXT: Think about Mr. Warwick's family
DIALOGUE AFTER: Cedric: Bill isn't the only one who's afraid. People all over the Commonwealth are talking about this Institute.
SCRIPT NOTES: Appealing to a guy for help. / Pleading

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: A man's life is at stake, and you're fishing for a bribe? You're pathetic.
RESPONSE TEXT: That's the sort of offer you'd expect from a Raider.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Cedric: Then I guess this conversation's over.
SCRIPT NOTES: Disgusted. / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: You'll only feel a slight prick.
SCRIPT NOTES: Said by an attacking Medical Mr. Handy

RESPONSE TEXT: Shall I administer some anesthesia?
SCRIPT NOTES: Said by an attacking Medical Mr. Handy

RESPONSE TEXT: A quick bit of minor surgery and this will all be over.
SCRIPT NOTES: Said by an attacking Medical Mr. Handy

RESPONSE TEXT: Hold still, would you?
SCRIPT NOTES: Said by an attacking Medical Mr. Handy

RESPONSE TEXT: Please stand still and we shall begin the procedure.
SCRIPT NOTES: Said by a Medical Mr. Handy after discovering the player

RESPONSE TEXT: Excuse me, should you be out of your room?
SCRIPT NOTES: Said by a Medical Mr. Handy after discovering the player

RESPONSE TEXT: Drinking Nuka Cola can help satiate thirst, increase energy and focus, as well as achieve dangerous glucose levels in diabetics.
SCRIPT NOTES: Said absently by a Medical Mr. Handy as they wander the halls

RESPONSE TEXT: In 4 out of 5 diagnoses, doctors recommend a nice cup of tea and a good lie down.
SCRIPT NOTES: Said absently by a Medical Mr. Handy as they wander the halls

RESPONSE TEXT: Feeling anxious? Over stimulated? Try smoking a refreshing cigarette. Dispensers are located on most patient floors.
SCRIPT NOTES: Said absently by a Medical Mr. Handy as they wander the halls

RESPONSE TEXT: Is the missus feeling jittery and distracted? Perhaps she's suffering from what leading doctors are calling "Lady's Hysteria."
SCRIPT NOTES: Said absently by a Medical Mr. Handy as they wander the halls

RESPONSE TEXT: Gray's Anatomy states that a removed spleen can result in a modest increase in white blood cells as well as a horrific, painful death.
SCRIPT NOTES: Said absently by a Medical Mr. Handy as they wander the halls

RESPONSE TEXT: If you haven't signed up for your quarter annual colonic, why not? Ask our receptionist today!
SCRIPT NOTES: Said absently by a Medical Mr. Handy as they wander the halls

RESPONSE TEXT: Good luck, General. I hope you find your son.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Ah, another fine mess of a parking garage. I wonder what awaits us this time.
SCRIPT NOTES: Sarcastic - Underground parking garage. / Sarcastic

RESPONSE TEXT: These underground areas are quite extensive.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed - in the ruins of the old Institute. Lots of tunnels and basement areas. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: That's enough to destroy our world all over again.
SCRIPT NOTES: Disbelief - Seeing a room with lots of nuclear bombs. / Disbelief

RESPONSE TEXT: Oh my, is this a launch site?
SCRIPT NOTES: Nervous - Seeing four missile silos. / Nervous

RESPONSE TEXT: If I'm not mistaken, and my database says I'm not, that's a pyramid.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed - seeing a pyramid which is actually the exterior of a military site. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: Plenty of cars down here. Wonder if any are still working.
SCRIPT NOTES: Curious - In a parking garage filled with cars. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Not bad for a Railroad secret base.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed - Secret railroad base in a penthouse office suite. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: I can't imagine anything friendly is hiding down here.
SCRIPT NOTES: Nervous - In the catacombs of the Old North church. / Nervous

RESPONSE TEXT: It's sad to see the Old North Church in such devastation. Although few may still be able to appreciate it.
SCRIPT NOTES: Sad - In the Old North Church that's in pretty bad shape. / Sad

RESPONSE TEXT: Please tell me we're heading back down.
SCRIPT NOTES: Worried - At the top of Trinity Towers. Codsworth doesn't like heights. / Worried

RESPONSE TEXT: Oh my. Mum, please tell me we're heading back down.
SCRIPT NOTES: Worried - At the top of Trinity Towers. Codsworth doesn't like heights. / Worried

RESPONSE TEXT: Please tell me we aren't going to the top. I can't imagine what the years have done to this building's stability.
SCRIPT NOTES: Worried - Looking up at Trinity Tower, a very tall building. Codsworth doesn't like heights. / Worried

RESPONSE TEXT: Looking for the next issue of Grognak, sir?
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused, asking jokingly - inside a comic book store. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Looking for the next issue of Grognak, mum?
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused, asking jokingly - inside a comic book store. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Why, it's the Silver Shroud sound stage. My, but it's... low budget.
SCRIPT NOTES: Excited at first. Then a little less impressed - Finding the Silver Shroud sound stage. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Sir, I do hope you know what you're doing helping this... captain.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned - Doesn't like the idea of helping a Chinese Ghoul. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Mum, I do hope you know what you're doing helping this... captain.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned - Doesn't like the idea of helping a Chinese Ghoul. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: An impressive bit of machinery... for communist wankers.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed - In the engine room of a working Chinese sub. He's impressed, but not too happy about it. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: Hmph. I suppose the red bastards deserve some credit for the state of this submarine.
SCRIPT NOTES: Slightly irritated - On the main bridge of a "working" Chinese submarine. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: I wonder what movie was playing that accursed day.
SCRIPT NOTES: Curious and slightly sad - In the projection room of a drive in. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: It looks like a movie was showing when the bombs fell.
SCRIPT NOTES: Matter of fact - at the drive in with lots of cars parked in front of the screen. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: This room's a sight for sore sensors. I wonder who's been keeping it up all this time.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed and curious - finding an office in very good shape. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: Ah, the Giddyup Buttercup. Bringing those dreams of owning a pony to life... and with very little maintenance I might add.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed - Seeing a Giddyup Buttercup that may still be working. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: I wonder how many people these days are given a proper burial.
SCRIPT NOTES: Curious - In the middle of a big cemetery.  / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Are we going in there, sir? You know how much I love water.
SCRIPT NOTES: MARK FOR RE-RECORD.Sarcastic - The main room of a water treatment plant is entirely flooded. / Sarcastic

RESPONSE TEXT: Are we going in there, mum? You know how much I love water.
SCRIPT NOTES: Sarcastic - The main room of a water treatment plant is entirely flooded. / Sarcastic

RESPONSE TEXT: Looks like someone was preparing for the worst. I wonder if the people here survived.
SCRIPT NOTES: Curious - Inside a small backyard bunker. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Just another welcoming and friendly neighborhood in the Commonwealth.
SCRIPT NOTES: Sarcastically happy - This neighborhood is fortified and filled with Super Mutants. / Sarcastic

RESPONSE TEXT: Thoreau's cabin survived the bombs. I'm sure he never thought it'd take a nuclear war to bring us back to humble living.
SCRIPT NOTES: Slightly amused - Finding Thoreau's cabin. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Quite disturbing down here, is it not?
SCRIPT NOTES: Nervous and disturbed - In a morgue basement. / Nervous

RESPONSE TEXT: Look, sir, no wait. Medical miracles do exist.
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused/joking/sarcastic - In the large waiting room of an old hospital. / Sarcastic

RESPONSE TEXT: Look, mum, no wait. Medical miracles do exist.
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused/joking/sarcastic - In the large waiting room of an old hospital. / Sarcastic

RESPONSE TEXT: I've the most incredible urge to rearrange those chairs in a more perfect circle.
SCRIPT NOTES: Matter of fact - Seeing an office with chairs arranged in a circle. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Ah, this must be the heart of the vault.
SCRIPT NOTES: Matter of fact - the large reactor room of a vault. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: By Jove!
SCRIPT NOTES: Horrified, but in a half whisper - Seeing part of a corpse as it gets eating and dragged away out of view. / Disbelief

RESPONSE TEXT: Uh... sir, if I may. I don't think it's entirely safe here.
SCRIPT NOTES: Worried and nervous - Hearing a large creature moving around above your head. A bit shakey and almost whispering. / Worried

RESPONSE TEXT: Uh... mum, if I may. I don't think it's entirely safe here.
SCRIPT NOTES: Worried and nervous - Hearing a large creature moving around above your head. A bit shakey and almost whispering. / Worried

RESPONSE TEXT: Curious. It's a replica of the surface. I wonder what it was used for.
SCRIPT NOTES: Curious - Seeing a replica of the surface, only it's destroyed. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Vault-Tec certainly made some odd location choices. Although in this case, they could be guarding the future.
SCRIPT NOTES: Matter of fact. Finding a vault entrance in a school basement. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: You don't suppose this vault was unfinished when the bombs fell? I can't imagine exposed dirt was the look they were going for.
SCRIPT NOTES: Curious, then slightly disgusted at the 2nd sentence. Seeing an exposed cave room with machinery while exploring Vault 114. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Oh dear, is that... mum?
SCRIPT NOTES: Worried at first... Then realizes it's the body of the player's spouse. "Mum" addresses the corpse. Very upset, almost shaken at seeing the body. / Sad

RESPONSE TEXT: Sir, I'm... I'm so sorry.
SCRIPT NOTES: Very sad and apologetic. Seeing the player's dead spouse. / Sad

RESPONSE TEXT: Oh dear, is that... sir?
SCRIPT NOTES: Worried at first... Then realizes it's the body of the player's spouse. "Sir" addresses the corpse. Very upset, almost shaken at seeing the body. / Sad

RESPONSE TEXT: Mum, I'm... I'm so sorry.
SCRIPT NOTES: Very sad and apologetic. Seeing the player's dead spouse. / Sad

RESPONSE TEXT: A vault? Down here?
SCRIPT NOTES: Curious - Surprised to find a vault entrance in a subway tunnel. / Disbelief

RESPONSE TEXT: Hmm, strange for a church to have a theatrical rigging system. Perhaps the choir was planning an elaborate holiday performance.
SCRIPT NOTES: Curious - Being above the pulpit of a church and seeing ropes/sandbags there, as if set up for props for a play. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: This nursery looks well kept for the times. Gives renewed hope for the little ones, doesn't it? Er... apologies, sir. I wasn't thinking.
SCRIPT NOTES: Hopeful at first. Realizes he may have brought up a painful memory and then apologetic - upon seeing a nursery in a church basement. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: This nursery looks well kept for the times. Gives renewed hope for the little ones, doesn't it? Er... apologies, mum. I wasn't thinking.
SCRIPT NOTES: Hopeful at first. Realizes he may have brought up a painful memory and then apologetic - upon seeing a nursery in a church basement. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: I wonder how the quarry flooded. Rainfall perhaps? Or maybe they dug right into a spring.
SCRIPT NOTES: Curious - Seeing a quarry filled with water. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: A protectron down here? Someone was serious about their ale.
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused - seeing a protectron in the basement of the Shamrock Taphouse. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: I can hardly believe a place like this actually exists. I don't even feel the urge to clean.
SCRIPT NOTES: In awe of the Institute - Very clean, highly advanced. / Awed

RESPONSE TEXT: I'd be very dubious of the quality here. Sanitation looks to be at an all time low.
SCRIPT NOTES: Disgusted - The brewing vats of the Gwinnet Brewery. / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: Up for a tour of the ol' brewery, sir? I can't imagine they charge... although I can't vouch for the safety either.
SCRIPT NOTES: Jokingly at first, trails off into a bit of worry at the end - At the entrance to the Gwinnet Brewery. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Up for a tour of the ol' brewery, mum? I can't imagine they charge... although I can't vouch for the safety either.
SCRIPT NOTES: Jokingly at first, trails off into a bit of worry at the end - At the entrance to the Gwinnet Brewery. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Quite the theatrical set up back here. I can only imagine the elaborate plays that were performed here.
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused - Behind the scenes of the Combat Zone, seeing the stage lifts. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: A cage? How uncivilized.
SCRIPT NOTES: Disgusted - The fighting cage at the Combat Zone. / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: Oh my, that was really quite deep.
SCRIPT NOTES: A bit nervous at seeing how deep the drained quarry is. / Nervous

RESPONSE TEXT: Impressive work on the ol' Castle, sir. I couldn't have done a better job myself.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed - After The Castle Courtyard has been rid of Mirelurks. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: Impressive work on the ol' Castle, mum. I couldn't have done a better job myself.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed - After The Castle Courtyard has been rid of Mirelurks. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: Watch your step, sir. So much dirt and debris. I can't imagine how long it'd take to sweep this place out.
SCRIPT NOTES: Cautioning at first. Then disgusted at the work it'd take to clean up - In the basement of The Castle. / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: Watch your step, mum. So much dirt and debris. I can't imagine how long it'd take to sweep this place out.
SCRIPT NOTES: Cautioning at first. Then disgusted at the work it'd take to clean up - In the basement of The Castle. / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: Sad to see Fort Independence in such a state. Mirelurks... disgusting.
SCRIPT NOTES: Disgusted - Seeing the Courtyard with Mirelurk clutter. / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: Ick. I can't imagine that was a pleasant fate.
SCRIPT NOTES: Disgusted - "Ick" can be any noise of disgust. Seeing a dead raider attacked by bugs. / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: Ah, the Boston Public Garden. And some of the swan boats are still intact.
SCRIPT NOTES: Nostalgic with his first line, impressed with the second. - approaching the Boston Public Gardens. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: Someone sure was thorough when it came to proper defenses.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed - Brotherhood of Steel barricades and defenses around the police station. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: I wonder how long that recording's been playing. It's quite intolerable.
SCRIPT NOTES: Irritated - Bunker is playing an old warning over and over. / Irritated

RESPONSE TEXT: Unfortunate. The passengers could have easily survived this crash. Not so sure about the fallout.
SCRIPT NOTES: Matter of fact, fading into sadness - Finding a crashed plane. The body is relatively intact. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: You know the old saying, sir, "One man's trash is another man's treasure."
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused - Seeing junk being old in a warehouse. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: You know the old saying, mum, "One man's trash is another man's treasure."
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused - Seeing junk being old in a warehouse. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Careful, sir. That heat isn't good for either of us.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned - Walking through areas of molten metal. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Careful, mum. That heat isn't good for either of us.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned - Walking through areas of molten metal. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: This place is just full of charm, isn't it?
SCRIPT NOTES: Very Sarcastic - Entering a blast furnace room with power armored raiders. / Sarcastic

RESPONSE TEXT: Poor things. I'm sure all they wanted was to go peacefully in their sleep.
SCRIPT NOTES: Sad - Seeing skeletons of prewar residents still in their beds as an old folks home. / Sad

RESPONSE TEXT: Oh, sir, I can't help but think of the memories you could have had here.
SCRIPT NOTES: Sad - seeing an old playground. / Sad

RESPONSE TEXT: Oh, mum, I can't help but think of the memories you could have had here.
SCRIPT NOTES: Sad - seeing an old playground. / Sad

RESPONSE TEXT: This must have been the ranger station. Good to see the ol' flag still standing.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed - Entering an old ranger cabin. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: That looks like a military grade robot, and still in working order. Better hope it's friendly.
SCRIPT NOTES: Matter of fact at first. Concerned with the last sentence - seeing a military robot slightly barricaded in with a bunch of stuff. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: This must have been quite the pleasant boardwalk back in the day. Vendors, tourists, maybe even a little live entertainment.
SCRIPT NOTES: Nostalgic - Standing on the boardwalk at a beach. / Happy

RESPONSE TEXT: Oh, this is where we turn around, right, sir?
SCRIPT NOTES: Worried - Seeing a raider stronghold at the end of a tunnel. / Worried

RESPONSE TEXT: Oh, this is where we turn around, right, mum?
SCRIPT NOTES: Worried - Seeing a raider stronghold at the end of a tunnel. / Worried

RESPONSE TEXT: What sort of desperate times bring two brothers to fratricide?
SCRIPT NOTES: Curious and sad - At the scene of a mutual fratricide. / Somber

RESPONSE TEXT: So sad, sir. I do hope she wasn't alone when the bombs fell.
SCRIPT NOTES: Serious/Sad - Seeing the skeleton of a pre-war runaway girl. / Somber

RESPONSE TEXT: So sad, mum. I do hope she wasn't alone when the bombs fell.
SCRIPT NOTES: Serious/Sad - Seeing the skeleton of a pre-war runaway girl. / Somber

RESPONSE TEXT: I do hope this overpass holds out long enough for us to get back down... safely, I should say.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned - On an old overpass that's falling apart. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Well, this place has certainly seen better days.
SCRIPT NOTES: Matter of fact - Settlement that's been taken over by Gunners. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: I hate to think of what happened here.
SCRIPT NOTES: Somber/Sad - Seeing the aftermath of a food riot massacre. / Somber

RESPONSE TEXT: Sir, I do hope you're certain this turbine is no longer functional. The implications if it were to turn on are... not good.
SCRIPT NOTES: Worried/Concerned - Inside an old water turbine. / Worried

RESPONSE TEXT: Mum, I do hope you're certain this turbine is no longer functional. The implications if it were to turn on are... not good.
SCRIPT NOTES: Worried/Concerned - Inside an old water turbine. / Worried

RESPONSE TEXT: These generators have seen better days.
SCRIPT NOTES: Matter of fact - Observing a room full of rusty old generators. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: I imagine these buttons may activate some changes within those rooms below.
SCRIPT NOTES: Curious / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Sir, my sensors indicate a high level of chemicals in the air. I wouldn't linger here.
SCRIPT NOTES: Cautioning the player - In a room with an unknown gas in the air. Possibly al chemical weapon. / Worried

RESPONSE TEXT: Mum, my sensors indicate a high level of chemicals in the air. I wouldn't linger here.
SCRIPT NOTES: Cautioning the player - In a room with an unknown gas in the air. Possibly al chemical weapon. / Worried

RESPONSE TEXT: Ghastly. I hope these weren't based off experience.
SCRIPT NOTES: Disturbed and disgusted - In a room filled with paintings of serial murders. / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: To think some poor soul once called this place home.
SCRIPT NOTES: Somewhat sympathetic - Seeing an old abandoned camp by a sinkhole in a cave. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Fiddler's Green is in surprisingly good shape. Some of those trailers look better than most houses.
SCRIPT NOTES: Slightly impressed - Looking at a trailer park. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: An ideal spot for some light camping, I'd say. Minus the mirelurks, of course.
SCRIPT NOTES: Matter of fact - Cabins surrounded by a Mirelurk breeding ground / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: This power station appears to be in quite a state of disrepair.
SCRIPT NOTES: Matter of fact - Making an observation - At an old power station. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Careful, sir. No telling how unstable the surrounding area may be.
SCRIPT NOTES: Cautioning the player - A large portion of shore has been washed away, leaving a bit of a cliff behind. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Careful, mum. No telling how unstable the surrounding area may be.
SCRIPT NOTES: Cautioning the player - A large portion of shore has been washed away, leaving a bit of a cliff behind. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: You can't deny the enduring quality of General Atomics International. Although, I can't imagine cycling through that for the past 200 years.
SCRIPT NOTES: Proud at first. 2nd sentence is more sympathetic. - At seeing another Mister Handy reciting facts about the sea in a museum. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: I wonder what happened here. Tanks this size don't break easily.
SCRIPT NOTES: Curious - Lab room with smashed fish tanks (very large tanks). / Puzzled

RESPONSE TEXT: What manner of savagery is this?
SCRIPT NOTES: Disgusted - Found an interrogation room with torture implements and blood. / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: That's one "do it yourself" project I wouldn't touch with a ten foot pole.
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused - Hidden room where a bomb was being made. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Oh dear. Please don't tell me those Super Mutants are aspiring surgeons.
SCRIPT NOTES: Disgusted - Found an operating theater room filled with Super Mutant meat bags and a skeleton on the operating table. / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: Just think. Whoever owned anything here has long since passed away.
SCRIPT NOTES: Sadly serious - inside a bank safe. / Somber

RESPONSE TEXT: Quite a novel idea, building a ramshackle town on an overpass. Especially if you hate yard work.

RESPONSE TEXT: It looks like this was once quite the settlement, sir. I hate to think what became of the settlers.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned - In a settlement that got massacred by the Institute. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: It looks like this was once quite the settlement, mum. I hate to think what became of the settlers.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned - In a settlement that got massacred by the Institute. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: With a view like this, it's a wonder we're still alive. Either that or our late friend here shouldn't have quit his day job.
SCRIPT NOTES: Matter of fact - Up in a good sniping area, having just killed the sniper in it. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: I'll never understand such blatant disrespect for Mother Nature.
SCRIPT NOTES: Disgusted - Looking at tons of barrels of waste being dumped  / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: That's an unfortunate water feature for you.
SCRIPT NOTES: Slight disgust - Pool filled with radioactive waste and spewing up small geysers. / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: Ah nothing like the warm glow of a fusion reactor, wouldn't you agree, sir?
SCRIPT NOTES: Happy - looking at a glowing fusion reactor. / Happy

RESPONSE TEXT: Ah nothing like the warm glow of a fusion reactor, wouldn't you agree, mum?
SCRIPT NOTES: Happy - looking at a glowing fusion reactor. / Happy

RESPONSE TEXT: Please don't tell me we're going all the way up there, sir? I can already feel my acrophobia taking hold.
SCRIPT NOTES: Nervous - Looking up thirty stories. and afraid of heights. / Nervous

RESPONSE TEXT: Please don't tell me we're going all the way up there, mum? I can already feel my acrophobia taking hold.
SCRIPT NOTES: Nervous - Looking up thirty stories. and afraid of heights. / Nervous

RESPONSE TEXT: Never a dull moment in the subway stations.
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused and observing - Fight between raiders and synths in the subway. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Quite the stock they have here. I'd be certain there's a market for 200 year old irradiated fish.
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused - Area has tons of boxes on the shelves. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Sir, I believe that man just shut us in.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned - An NPC has trapped him and the player in a basement. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Mum, I believe that man just shut us in.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned - An NPC has trapped him and the player in a basement. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Looks like the "mystery meat" mystery has been solved... Just goes to show, some things are better left unanswered.

RESPONSE TEXT: I say, Vault-Tec really does enjoy crossing the line, don't they? Watching these poor souls like animals in a lab.
SCRIPT NOTES: Slight disgust - Finding an observation room where Vault-Tec was secretly watching people in the vault. / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: Quite the garden maze of hallways, isn't it? One could easily get lost down here.
SCRIPT NOTES: Making conversation - In an unused secret area of a vault. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Heading in, are we, sir? Just... try not to fall overboard.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned - more for himself then the player. Codsworth doesn't like water. - Heading into a town made of boats/ships. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Have I mentioned I'm afraid of heights? Especially ones with ramshackle crumbly bits?
SCRIPT NOTES: Nervous with a fear of heights - on top of a the end of an upturned ship that raiders have turned into a shack town. / Nervous

RESPONSE TEXT: Sir, I'm picking up dangerously high levels of radiation. Best not linger here if you value your health.
SCRIPT NOTES: Warning the player - In water with high levels of radiation. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Mum, I'm picking up dangerously high levels of radiation. Best not linger here if you value your health.
SCRIPT NOTES: Warning the player - In water with high levels of radiation. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: That's one way to light up your lighthouse.
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused - A lighthouse being lit up by glowing ones. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: At least radio is still alive these days. I wonder if they'll ever manage to revive the telly.
SCRIPT NOTES: Matter of fact, somewhat curious in the 2nd sentence - coming up on a radio station. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: I imagine there's not many to view these items as "treasure" anymore these days.
SCRIPT NOTES: Nostalgic and slightly sad - finding a time-capsule room with several pre-war items / Somber

RESPONSE TEXT: This is certainly an unexpected amount of security. You don't suppose a real treasure actually exists?
SCRIPT NOTES: Curious - Suddenly lots of security for no reason Codsworth is aware of.  / Puzzled

RESPONSE TEXT: Ah yes, nothing like cozying up to a barrel of nuclear waste for the night.
SCRIPT NOTES: Being sarcastic - Radioactive barrels in a bar with beds around it. / Sarcastic

RESPONSE TEXT: I wonder what brought the roof down on this one.
SCRIPT NOTES: Curious - Looking at the caved in roof in the middle of a store. / Puzzled

RESPONSE TEXT: Looks like the hand that feeds them has become the food.
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused and disgusted - Seeing a man killed by pet mirelurks. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: I shudder to think of what happened here. Mankind can be so cruel.
SCRIPT NOTES: Disgusted and disturbed - Seeing a cellblock where patients were experimented on. / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: And of course the crater comes with its own welcoming party of Feral Ghouls.
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused and nervous - At the bottom of an irradiated crater filled with feral ghouls. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Watch your step, sir. Don't want to topple in unexpectedly.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned/Warning the player - At seeing a large crater in the ground. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Watch your step, mum. Don't want to topple in unexpectedly.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned/Warning the player - At seeing a large crater in the ground. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Such a pleasant view. I wonder if whoever lived here ever took the time to notice.
SCRIPT NOTES: Slightly happy - Nice view from the top of a building where Raiders had built a shack. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: What a perfect little studying spot this would have been back then.
SCRIPT NOTES: Matter of fact - Looking at a school library with skylights. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Feel like taking the high road? It appears that crane can get us there.
SCRIPT NOTES: Observing, slightly joking - seeing a crane you could walk on to reach an above highway. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Such a reminder of the days before the war. Perhaps even I took things for granted back then.
SCRIPT NOTES: Nostalgic, slightly sad - In a showroom floor for Hester's Robotics. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Looks like these Raiders became quite the Feral feast.
SCRIPT NOTES: Observing with slight disgust - Seeing dead raiders being eaten by Feral Ghouls / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Ah the ol' College Square. To think this place used to be a hub of activity.
SCRIPT NOTES: Nostalgic, slightly sad - Seeing College Square / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Care to poke around a bit, sir? There's quite an abundance of stuff here that may prove useful.
SCRIPT NOTES: Asking a question - Seeing shelves filled with appliances/building items. / Question

RESPONSE TEXT: Care to poke around a bit, mum? There's quite an abundance of stuff here that may prove useful.
SCRIPT NOTES: Asking a question - Seeing shelves filled with appliances/building items. / Question

RESPONSE TEXT: Sir, I daresay we're not alone here.
SCRIPT NOTES: Nervous/Worried - Feels an ambush coming on / Nervous

RESPONSE TEXT: Mum, I daresay we're not alone here.
SCRIPT NOTES: Nervous/Worried - Feels an ambush coming on / Nervous

RESPONSE TEXT: Impressively still intact here. A wonder it wasn't a direct target.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed and curious - in the command center of a base. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: This must be the clinic's storage. Bloody impressive, wouldn't you say, sir?
SCRIPT NOTES: Making a bad joke - Found the storage room for the blood bank where they stored the blood. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: This must be the clinic's storage. Bloody impressive, wouldn't you say, mum?
SCRIPT NOTES: Making a bad joke - Found the storage room for the blood bank where they stored the blood. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Are they... growing something in that pool?
SCRIPT NOTES: Curious - Came across ghouls growing tarberries in a swimming pool. / Puzzled

RESPONSE TEXT: I wonder what they're doing. Racing, you suppose?
SCRIPT NOTES: Curious - seeing people racing each other in power armor. / Puzzled

RESPONSE TEXT: Would've been nice to have a spot of tea here back then with all the natural light.
SCRIPT NOTES: Matter of fact - Upon seeing a large dome window above a cafeteria area. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: I can't imagine the rush this place felt when they got word of the first bombings.
SCRIPT NOTES: Thoughtful - At the ruins of a news station. Recalling the news of the first bombs dropping. / Thinking

RESPONSE TEXT: I remember when beaches used to be pleasant vacation spots. Now they're just mirelurk breeding grounds.
SCRIPT NOTES: Nostalgic and then disgusted. - Walking on a Mirelurk infested beach. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Nothing like quality assurance testing. Guaranteeing the finest products in the nation.
SCRIPT NOTES: Proud - Walking through the old Quality Assurance testing area of General Atomics. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: Fancy a game, sir? Something tells me the bumpers are no longer available.
SCRIPT NOTES: Joking - Found an old bowling alley. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Fancy a game, mum? Something tells me the bumpers are no longer available.
SCRIPT NOTES: Joking - Found an old bowling alley. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Ah General Atomics. Only the topmost quality in consumer robotics.
SCRIPT NOTES: Proud - Looking upon a giant Mister Handy statue at the General Atomics Center. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: Quite the weapons cache, sir. Could prove useful.
SCRIPT NOTES: Matter-of-fact - Finding a stockpile of weapons and ammo. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Quite the weapons cache, mum. Could prove useful.
SCRIPT NOTES: Matter-of-fact - Finding a stockpile of weapons and ammo. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Oh my. Bit nerve wracking, isn't it? Being around so many weapons of devastation?
SCRIPT NOTES: Slightly nervous - Finding a huge stash of bombs. / Nervous

RESPONSE TEXT: Curious. I wouldn't think any of these old trains would still be running.
SCRIPT NOTES: Curious - Seeing a running train. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: It won't be long until Mother Nature reclaims this one.
SCRIPT NOTES: Matter-of-fact - Looking at a flooded town, assuming the structures are so unstable, they'll soon collapse leaving nothing but a lake. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Ah a secret, underground base! Right out of the ol' spy novel, wouldn't you say, sir?
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed and excited - They just entered a trap door in an old shack and find a huge building underneath. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: Ah a secret, underground base! Right out of the ol' spy novel, wouldn't you say, mum?
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed and excited - They just entered a trap door in an old shack and find a huge building underneath. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: I believe a Mr. Samuel Adams would be rolling in his grave to see the Cradle of Liberty littered with such... atrocities.
SCRIPT NOTES: Disgusted - Entering the main space of Faneuil Hall and seeing all sorts of gross nets filled with mutilated body parts hanging from the ceiling. / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: Sir, judging by my navigational sensors, we're now directly beneath Concord.
SCRIPT NOTES: Matter-of-Fact - They're in a sewer beneath Concord. Codsworth is just stating a fact. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Mum, judging by my navigational sensors, we're now directly beneath Concord.
SCRIPT NOTES: Matter-of-Fact - They're in a sewer beneath Concord. Codsworth is just stating a fact. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Sir, I'm picking up the sounds of a fairly... large creature taking a snooze. Best be on the quiet side.
SCRIPT NOTES: Worried/Cautious and speaking very quietly - He's picked up the sound of a big nasty Deathclaw snoring. / Worried

RESPONSE TEXT: Mum, I'm picking up the sounds of a fairly... large creature taking a snooze. Best be on the quiet side.
SCRIPT NOTES: Worried/Cautious and speaking very quietly - He's picked up the sound of a big nasty Deathclaw snoring. / Worried

RESPONSE TEXT: I'm guessing we won't find a welcome mat here.
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused - Noticing a bunch of fortifications on a house. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: What a quaint little cul-de-sac. A wonder nobody seems to be home.
SCRIPT NOTES: First sentence is Impressed. Second drifts off into paranoia. Finding a cul-de-sac with perfectly good houses, but no one living in them. / Puzzled

RESPONSE TEXT: What is it about empty tourist attractions that can be so haunting?
SCRIPT NOTES: Paranoid - At the dry dock of a mostly abandoned boat tour area. / Nervous

RESPONSE TEXT: Ah the nerve center of this charade. Sir, I beg you to shut this place down.
SCRIPT NOTES: First sentence is relief. Second is a determined plea to the player - Said upon finding the terminals that are being used to control the robots. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Ah the nerve center of this charade. Mum, I beg you to shut this place down.
SCRIPT NOTES: First sentence is relief. Second is a determined plea to the player - Said upon finding the terminals that are being used to control the robots. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: I say! General Atomics' finest, reprogrammed as simple... race horses for bloody Raiders? Appalling!
SCRIPT NOTES: Disgusted - Discovering a race track where Raiders have reprogrammed Mr. Handies as the "horses". / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: Oh my. I dread to think about what's going on here.
SCRIPT NOTES: Worried/Concerned - Seeing prison cages in a run down school. / Worried

RESPONSE TEXT: If you ask me, that little water hole is more than a tad suspect.
SCRIPT NOTES: Suspicious - Seeing a  murky water hole (about the size of a hot tub) in the middle of a small round cave. / Suspicious

RESPONSE TEXT: Hard to believe a tunnel system so vast was all for a bit of rock.
SCRIPT NOTES: Suspicious - Either looking up or down a huge pit in a quarry with a lot of tunnels. / Suspicious

RESPONSE TEXT: Now here's an unexpected surprise. Perhaps there was a tad bit of humane treatment here after all.
SCRIPT NOTES: Slight Surprise, kind of impressed and relieved - Finding a courtyard in a creepy old asylum. / Surprised

RESPONSE TEXT: I can't imagine this meant good news for the patients here.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned - Coming upon a lab area of sorts where patients were probably illegally operated on. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Could it be more ghastly down here? A wonder anyone would recover in a place like this.
SCRIPT NOTES: Creeped out - Entering an old, creepy insane asylum. Emphasis on the words "be more"... Could it BE MORE ghastly down here? / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: Either these boats washed up here, or some hooligans had themselves quite the party.
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused and Curious - Seeing several old boats piled around to form a pathway across a river. Kind of like a "boat dam". / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Oh yes. Nothing to see here but a ship stuck in a skyscraper.
SCRIPT NOTES: Sarcastic/Disbelief - There's a huge ship that looks like it got stuck on the top of a skyscraper. / Disbelief

RESPONSE TEXT: This ship looks quite the mystery. Run aground on a bank and not a scratch on her!
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed and mystified - Looking at a huge ship on top of a bank building. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: Gives new meaning to the phrase "cute and cuddly".
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused - Looking over the corpse of a Raider who was just killed wearing a big, happy bear mascot head. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Quite a bit of force was required to punch out this floor. It's impressive and yet... disconcerting.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed, but concerned at "and yet..." Reacting to a large hole punched through the floor of school into the subway system below. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: Yuck. Nothing quite as becoming as waterlogged Ghouls.
SCRIPT NOTES: Disgusted - Entered a basement full of ghouls laying in water. "Yuck" isn't literal. Just make a grossed out noise, like eewwuh/ew/yech/etc. / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: Ah yes, the moment I see a nuclear crater, I think, "Home, sweet home."
SCRIPT NOTES: Sarcastic - Observing a settlement built in a nuke crater. / Sarcastic

RESPONSE TEXT: If Raiders barricaded this tunnel, I hate to think of what they're defending against.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned/Worried - Raiders have barricaded a tunnel to defend against something deeper inside. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Ah the Corvega. I like to think of it as a distant cousin.
SCRIPT NOTES: Happy nostalgic - They're at an old car factory that made cars with atomic engines, probably similar to stuff that Codsworth runs on. / Happy

RESPONSE TEXT: Who'd have thought Super Mutants fancied a bit of dress up?
SCRIPT NOTES: Highly amused - Encountering Super Mutants wearing sailor hats. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Here's something you don't see everyday.
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused - A tugboat has gotten itself stuck between the two sides of a drawbridge.  / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: I hope the owner of that boat knew how to swim.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned - Looking at an overturned rowboat in the middle of a deep pond. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: My olfactory sensors are picking up quite the stench, sir. You may want to plug your nose.
SCRIPT NOTES: First sentence is stating fact. Second one is with warning. They're coming up on a library that Super Mutants may have been using as a bathroom. / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: My olfactory sensors are picking up quite the stench, mum. You may want to plug your nose.
SCRIPT NOTES: First sentence is stating fact. Second one is with warning. They're coming up on a library that Super Mutants may have been using as a bathroom. / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: Moments like this make me thankful I've no stomach.
SCRIPT NOTES: Grossed out - Walking into a cafeteria with sacks of body parts hanging from the ceiling. / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: Something tells me the acting is as genius as the set design.
SCRIPT NOTES: Sarcastic - Looking at an old amphitheater with a set made of random boards and rusted metal siding. / Sarcastic

RESPONSE TEXT: Sir, I do believe that fridge requires your attention.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned - He's heard a cry for help from a nearby refrigerator. There's someone trapped inside. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Mum, I do believe that fridge requires your attention.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned - He's heard a cry for help from a nearby refrigerator. There's someone trapped inside. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Such a fine establishment back in the day.
SCRIPT NOTES: Sad and nostalgic - Recalling the great company this used to be. / Sad

RESPONSE TEXT: I believe the title "mad scientist" would be appropriate here.
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused by a bizarre collection of science gadgets. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Can it be? A residence untouched by time?
SCRIPT NOTES: Curious and impressed: Seeing a really nice place amongst ruin. / Disbelief

RESPONSE TEXT: Damage aside, the fact that the monument still stands is a testament to human architecture.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: Oh my. The poor souls.
SCRIPT NOTES: Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: It's a shame to see everything in such ruin.
SCRIPT NOTES: Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: I wonder how many of the books survived. Today's humanity could greatly benefit from any knowledge within these walls.
SCRIPT NOTES: Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Up for a bit of sport, sir? I could give you quite the run for your money.
SCRIPT NOTES: Happy

RESPONSE TEXT: Up for a bit of sport, mum? I could give you quite the run for your money.
SCRIPT NOTES: Happy

RESPONSE TEXT: Quite the pleasant little courtyard.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: Sir, no matter what may befall us, I hope suicide is never an answer you seek.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Mum, no matter what may befall us, I hope suicide is never an answer you seek.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: An abandoned brewery? No doubt we'll find plenty of unsavory types here.
SCRIPT NOTES: Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: This fountain is quite the visual respite.
SCRIPT NOTES: Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Ah, I do so miss shopping expeditions.
SCRIPT NOTES: Nostalgic / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: What a quaint little speakeasy. It looks like it attracted only the highest caliber customers, too.
SCRIPT NOTES: Sarcastic

RESPONSE TEXT: The Defense Intelligence Agency? I wonder how much they knew before the first bombs fell.
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: What's the old saying, sir? Finders, keepers?
SCRIPT NOTES: Surprised

RESPONSE TEXT: What's the old saying, mum? Finders, keepers?
SCRIPT NOTES: Surprised

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Remember, the synths are the primary objective. Harm must be avoided at all costs.
RESPONSE TEXT: The Institute would put innocents in danger just to reclaim their Synths?
DIALOGUE AFTER: X418: Here are the recall codes. Follow me.
SCRIPT NOTES: Wary / Concerned

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Easy. I just didn't know there were any other Minutemen out there.
RESPONSE TEXT: An innocent mistake, mum.
DIALOGUE AFTER: RonnieShaw: Yeah, I did take a pretty long vacation after Joe died. Not surprised you never heard of me.
SCRIPT NOTES: Not speaking to the player. Being apologetic for the player. / Apologetic

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'd like to see you try.
RESPONSE TEXT: I suppose I should have seen that coming.

SCRIPT NOTES: Amused and annoyed. / Amused

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I don't have time for a dick-measuring contest. What do you actually want?

DIALOGUE AFTER: RonnieShaw: You kiss your mother with that mouth? At least you're finally ready to get down to business.
SCRIPT NOTES: Telling the player his comment was unwise. / Neutral

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I don't have time for a dick-measuring contest. What do you actually want?

DIALOGUE AFTER: RonnieShaw: You kiss your mother with that mouth? At least you're finally ready to get down to business.
SCRIPT NOTES: Telling the player his comment was unwise. / Neutral

DIALOGUE AFTER: Desdemona: We'll deal with that later. We need to prepare for a Brotherhood assault.
SCRIPT NOTES: Relieved player isn't going to destroy the Railroad / Relieved

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Of course I'm not going to go through with it. So how do I deal with it?

SCRIPT NOTES: Shocked player wants to kill the Railroad / Surprised

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'm afraid you all have to die.
RESPONSE TEXT: Mum, no. You can't possibly be serious.

SCRIPT NOTES: Shocked player wants to kill the Railroad / Surprised

SCRIPT NOTES: Relieved the player isn't killing the Railroad / Relieved

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You're alive, so what do you think?
RESPONSE TEXT: Good answer, mum. I was worried for a moment.

SCRIPT NOTES: Wants the PC to not kill a man / Concerned

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: After all you've done? They'll trust you. And I'll make sure no one else finds out about me.

SCRIPT NOTES: Wants the PC to not kill a man / Concerned

DIALOGUE BEFORE: BoS301Duff: I'm afraid something terrible has happened to her.
RESPONSE TEXT: Oh dear. I hope she's all right.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Don't worry, I'll find her.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned / Worried

DIALOGUE BEFORE: BoS301Scara: The whole thing's rather complicated, perhaps I'll explain it to you sometime.
RESPONSE TEXT: Such a curious name to give a child.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS301Scara: So, now that I've formally introduced myself, perhaps you'd care to tell me why you're here?
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused / Amused

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Because we care what happens to the Commonwealth.
RESPONSE TEXT: The Brotherhood may be our only chance at stopping the Institute.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS301Li: You know, if anyone else wearing a Brotherhood of Steel uniform said something like that, I'd laugh in their face.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned. / Concerned

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: If you don't work on Prime, I'll have you shot.
RESPONSE TEXT: Really, sir? Resorting to threats already?
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS301Li: You son of a bitch!
SCRIPT NOTES: Disapproving and surprised / Surprised

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: If you don't work on Prime, I'll have you shot.
RESPONSE TEXT: Really, mum? Resorting to threats already?
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS301Li: You son of a bitch!
SCRIPT NOTES: Disapproving and surprised / Surprised

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: If not for the Brotherhood, do it for Doctor Virgil.
RESPONSE TEXT: You must know what goes on here isn't right.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS301Li: What they did to Doctor Virgil was cruel... it was wrong. How could I be so blind?
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned / Concerned

DIALOGUE BEFORE: BoS301ChildofAtom: That is why they must be safeguarded.
RESPONSE TEXT: Spoken like a true fanatic.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I want to spread his, uhh, glory... Look, the bombs will get used, okay? Isn't that what you want?
SCRIPT NOTES: Disapproving - Thinks the guy is crazy / Sarcastic

RESPONSE TEXT: I hate to think of what happened here.
SCRIPT NOTES: Coming upon a scene of massive devastation. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: The poor soul.
SCRIPT NOTES: Looking at a corpse of a woman who attempted to wall herself off in a room to get away from Ghouls. She did not succeed. / Sad

RESPONSE TEXT: Better to pass here than be torn to shreds by Ferals.
SCRIPT NOTES: Feeling sorry for a dead man. / Sad

RESPONSE TEXT: You did the right thing, sir. Don't let that man tell you otherwise.
SCRIPT NOTES: Encouraging / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: You did the right thing, mum. Don't let that man tell you otherwise.
SCRIPT NOTES: Encouraging / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Paladin Danse was a good man, sir. I worry you're a bit... misguided.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Companion: That Maxson fella seemed like he knew what was best. Maybe you should've listened to him.
SCRIPT NOTES: Worried the player made a bad decision / Worried

RESPONSE TEXT: Paladin Danse was a good man, mum. I worry you're a bit... misguided.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Companion: That Maxson fella seemed like he knew what was best. Maybe you should've listened to him.
SCRIPT NOTES: Worried the player made a bad decision / Worried

RESPONSE TEXT: Paladin Danse was a good man, sir. I don't believe this Elder Maxson is cut from the same cloth.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Companion: I wished you had the bollocks to do that yourself. At least it's over with.
SCRIPT NOTES: Sad over Danse's death. Wary of Maxson. / Sad

RESPONSE TEXT: Paladin Danse was a good man, mum. I don't believe this Elder Maxson is cut from the same cloth.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Companion: I wished you had the bollocks to do that yourself. At least it's over with.
SCRIPT NOTES: Sad over Danse's death. Wary of Maxson. / Sad

RESPONSE TEXT: Sir, you can't possibly be considering that order.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS302Maxson: I appreciate your cooperation.
SCRIPT NOTES: Shocked the player has chosen to kill someone. / Surprised

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: With pleasure. I'll make him pay for lying to us.
RESPONSE TEXT: Mum, you can't possibly be considering that order.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS302Maxson: I appreciate your cooperation.
SCRIPT NOTES: Shocked the player has chosen to kill someone. / Surprised

DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS302Maxson: You will do it. This is not up for judgment or debate!
SCRIPT NOTES: A little angry - Asked to kill a friend revealed to be a synth.  / Angry

DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS302Maxson: This isn't a request that requires an answer, Knight. This is a direct order.
SCRIPT NOTES: Hoping the player will say no. / Conspiratorial

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I don't know what to say.
RESPONSE TEXT: Mum, I believe the answer you are looking for is "no".
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS302Maxson: This isn't a request that requires an answer, Knight. This is a direct order.
SCRIPT NOTES: Hoping the player will say no. / Conspiratorial

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Isn't there some other way?
RESPONSE TEXT: Surely, you can't be that unforgiving.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS302Maxson: Absolutely not. My decision is final.
SCRIPT NOTES: Worried about the fate of Paladin Danse. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: I fear so much history will soon be forgotten.

RESPONSE TEXT: I wonder what the talk around the water cooler was on the day before the bombs dropped.

RESPONSE TEXT: Mr. Valentine's made quite a few friends along the way. Let's just hope they aren't enough to stop us from finding young Shaun.
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused and a bit nervous. "Friends" meaning enemies. He's made a lot of enemies by being good at his job. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Hot on Kellogg's trail, aren't we, sir? I can't wait to see the look on his face when we find him, and give him what for!
SCRIPT NOTES: Excited on the hunt - being chatty / Happy

RESPONSE TEXT: That airship was quite impressive. Whoever this Brotherhood is, let's hope they're friendly.

RESPONSE TEXT: Cybernetic brains and memory extractions. It's all a bit... unnerving.
SCRIPT NOTES: Disturbed. / Nervous

RESPONSE TEXT: I certainly hope there are no side affects after traipsing about in the mind of that... mercenary.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned. "mercenary" said with disgust. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: I must confess, it's a bit of a wonder to hear intelligence coming from a Super Mutant. Let's just hope Doctor Virgil still knows what he's doing.
SCRIPT NOTES: Upbeat, impressed. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: Sir, please be sure to exercise a bit of wisdom when it comes to handing over that chip.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned - wants the player to make a good decision. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: It's fascinating you intend to build something so complex out of the dregs of the Commonwealth.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed - player is going to build something high tech out of salvage / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: Why, that would mean it's conceivable to continue building all sorts of complex machinery with these mere... leftovers.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed that the player is going to make something high tech out of salvage. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: Thank heavens you've returned. You've no idea how distressing it is to see someone vanish into thin air.
SCRIPT NOTES: Relieved / Relieved

SCRIPT NOTES: Sad, apologetic. Slightly nervous for not sharing in the victory of the Prydwen's destruction. / Sad

RESPONSE TEXT: Misguided, yes, but... they didn't deserve to share that fate.
SCRIPT NOTES: Sad, apologetic. Slightly nervous for not sharing in the victory of the Prydwen's destruction. / Sad

RESPONSE TEXT: Misguided, yes, but... they didn't deserve to share that fate.

RESPONSE TEXT: I only want to caution you, sir, about putting yourself even more in harm's way.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned about the player joining the Railroad. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: While I'm certain the Railroad has good intentions, going directly against the Institute may bring more attention than you wish.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned about the player joining the Railroad / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: I only want to caution you, mum, about putting yourself even more in harm's way.

SCRIPT NOTES: Complimenting the player. / Happy

RESPONSE TEXT: Quite the noble cause, mum. I hope the Railroad knows how lucky they are.
SCRIPT NOTES: Complimenting the player. / Happy

RESPONSE TEXT: Not too shabby. A real shame the Institute had to come and make such a mess of things.
SCRIPT NOTES: Making an observation. / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: Impeccable timing, sir. I shudder to think of the Railroad's fate had the Brotherhood beaten us here.
SCRIPT NOTES: Complimenting at first. Growing concern at the 2nd sentence. / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: Impeccable timing, mum. I shudder to think of the Railroad's fate had the Brotherhood beaten us here.
SCRIPT NOTES: Complimenting at first. Growing concern at the 2nd sentence. / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: If not for your complete trust in Mister Tom, I'm afraid I'd be quite the shambles right now.
SCRIPT NOTES: Slightly nervous, but trying to hide it  / Friendly

RESPONSE TEXT: You do trust him completely, right?
SCRIPT NOTES: A bit nervous / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: I suppose if I survive taking on the Brotherhood and the Institute, I could fancy myself a proper Mister Gusty.
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused thinking. Emphasis on AND in Brotherhood AND the Institute. Brotherhood is already defeated and they are coming for the Institute. / Thinking

RESPONSE TEXT: It's refreshing to see a bit of military order within the Commonwealth. Let's just hope their intentions are in the right place.
SCRIPT NOTES: Happy and then concerned. / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: Now that we've done them a proper turn, let's hope they can return the favor.
SCRIPT NOTES: Proud in what they've accomplished. / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: Sir, I realize you have military training, but I fear your decision may have been too abrupt.
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned the player made a bad decision joining the Brotherhood of Steel. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: The Brotherhood seems more concerned about their technology than the people of the Commonwealth.
SCRIPT NOTES: Explaining a concern / Concerned

SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned the player made a bad decision joining the Brotherhood of Steel. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: They seem more concerned about their technology than the people of the Commonwealth.
SCRIPT NOTES: Explaining a concern / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Glad those Super Mutants were too daft to use their nukes against us.
SCRIPT NOTES: Happy/Grateful. / Grateful

RESPONSE TEXT: Proctor Ingram has quite the mind for mechanics. If she can fix up Liberty Prime, no doubt I'd be good hands should I ever fail to self-maintain.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: To think the Brotherhood can so easily turn on someone as loyal as Paladin Danse.
SCRIPT NOTES: Distrusting of the Brotherhood. / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Paladin Danse may have been a synth, but he was better than most men. His fate was truly undeserved.
SCRIPT NOTES: Sad over Danse's death, but trying to sound firm. / Sad

RESPONSE TEXT: You did the right thing, sir. Although, something tells me Paladin Danse's struggle has only just begun.
SCRIPT NOTES: Encouraging / Friendly

RESPONSE TEXT: He spent his whole life hating synths, just to discover he's one of them.
SCRIPT NOTES: Reflecting, sad for Paladin Danse / Thinking

RESPONSE TEXT: You did the right thing, mum. Although, something tells me Paladin Danse's struggle has only just begun.
SCRIPT NOTES: Encouraging / Friendly

RESPONSE TEXT: He spent his whole life hating synths, just to discover he's one of them.
SCRIPT NOTES: Reflecting, sad for Paladin Danse / Thinking

SCRIPT NOTES: Sad reflection / Thinking

RESPONSE TEXT: Is that such a terrible thing?
SCRIPT NOTES: Sad, doesn't understand and feeling bad for the Railroad who was defeated / Question

RESPONSE TEXT: I hope this Beryllium Agitator is truly the last piece. As a fellow robot, the idea of seeing Liberty Prime functional is quite invigorating.
SCRIPT NOTES: Hopeful / Friendly

RESPONSE TEXT: Liberty Prime is a true testament to mankind's abilities. Let's just hope she's enough to get us inside the Institute.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed by the giant robot, Liberty Prime. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: The last thing Raiders need is an intelligent leader. It would make them a proper force to be reckoned with, that's for sure.
SCRIPT NOTES: Doesn't like the idea of a synth leading raiders / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: I'm not quite sure we're in the right here, sir. I simply don't understand why the Institute wants to deny synths their own life.
SCRIPT NOTES: Morally conflicted / Puzzled

RESPONSE TEXT: Two technological giants facing off. This should prove interesting.
SCRIPT NOTES: Nervous about the upcoming battle. / Nervous

RESPONSE TEXT: Hopefully, the Institute can learn that the power of persuasion is still alive and well. They don't have to resort to this kidnapping nonsense.
SCRIPT NOTES: Hopeful, slight disgust at "kidnapping nonsense" / Friendly

RESPONSE TEXT: Quite the interesting broadcast, sir. It'll be interesting to see how the Commonwealth reacts after so much... fear.
SCRIPT NOTES: Curious and concerned about the player's broadcast (could have been negative or positive) / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Quite the interesting broadcast, mum. It'll be interesting to see how the Commonwealth reacts after so much... fear.
SCRIPT NOTES: Curious and concerned about the player's broadcast (could have been negative or positive) / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Jolly good show, sir, taking on that... dreadful beast. Deathclaws...They couldn't have been more aptly named.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed. Player defeated a deathclaw. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: Jolly good show, mum, taking on that... dreadful beast. Deathclaws...They couldn't have been more aptly named.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impressed. Player defeated a deathclaw. / Impressed

RESPONSE TEXT: Time to clear out these crustaceans and get good ol' Fort Independence the inhabitants it deserves.
SCRIPT NOTES: Determined / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: Not bad for a days work, although, this place needs a lot more tidying up if you know what I mean.
SCRIPT NOTES: Proud, but the mess is worrying him as a robot butler / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: It's terrifying what radiation has wrought upon the Commonwealth. Seeing a mirelurk that big... What's next?
SCRIPT NOTES: Concerned about what other large, nasty creatures could be out there / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: I hope this armory is as good as Miss Shaw recalls. The Commonwealth needs all the protection it can get.
SCRIPT NOTES: Hopeful, upbeat / Friendly

RESPONSE TEXT: We're quite lucky all those weapons remained here untouched. I suppose we owe it to the mirelurks, keeping the real scavengers at bay.
SCRIPT NOTES: Happy about a situation, making an amused observation / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Looks like Fort Independence is back in business. Artillery like that should give Minutemen enemies quite the challenge.
SCRIPT NOTES: Happy and proud / Happy

RESPONSE TEXT: So it ends as it began. Fitting I suppose. If only the Institute was interested in helping improve the Commonwealth.
SCRIPT NOTES: Thoughtful - player has blown up the Institute with a nuke / Thinking

RESPONSE TEXT: Why none of these powerful groups want to help the actual people of the world we live in is beyond me.
SCRIPT NOTES: Thoughtful after the Institute has been destroyed. / Thinking
